Name: arkworks/algebra
Description: Libraries for finite field, elliptic curve, and polynomial arithmetic
Disclaimer: WARNING: This is an academic proof-of-concept prototype, and in particular has not received careful code review. This implementation is NOT ready for production use.

Name: arkworks/crypto-primitives
Description: Interfaces and implementations of cryptographic primitives, along with R1CS constraints for them
Disclaimer: WARNING: This is an academic proof-of-concept prototype, and in particular has not received careful code review. This implementation is NOT ready for production use.

Name: arkworks/curves
Description: Implementations of popular elliptic curves

Name: arkworks/gemini
Description: An elastic proof system based on arkworks
Disclaimer: This code is not meant for production use and has not been audited.

Name: arkworks/gm17
Description: A Rust library for the preprocessing zkSNARK of Groth and Maller
Disclaimer: WARNING: This is an academic proof-of-concept prototype, and in particular has not received careful code review. This implementation is NOT ready for production use.

Name: arkworks/groth16
Description: A Rust implementation of the Groth16 zkSNARK
Disclaimer: WARNING: This is an academic proof-of-concept prototype, and in particular has not received careful code review. This implementation is NOT ready for production use.

Name: arkworks/marlin
Description: A Rust library for the Marlin preprocessing zkSNARK
Disclaimer: WARNING: This is an academic prototype, and in particular has not received careful code review. This implementation is NOT ready for production use.

Name: arkworks/nonnative
Description: R1CS constraints for non-native field arithmetic
Disclaimer: WARNING: This is an academic proof-of-concept prototype; in particular, it has not received careful code review. This implementation is NOT ready for production use.

Name: arkworks/poly-commit
Description: A Rust library for polynomial commitments
Disclaimer: WARNING: This is an academic prototype, and in particular has not received careful code review. This implementation is NOT ready for production use.

Name: arkworks/r1cs-std
Description: R1CS constraints for bits, fields, and elliptic curves
Disclaimer: WARNING: This is an academic proof-of-concept prototype, and in particular has not received careful code review. This implementation is NOT ready for production use.

Name: arkworks/snark
Description: Interfaces for Relations and SNARKs for these relations
Disclaimer: WARNING: This is an academic proof-of-concept prototype, and in particular has not received careful code review. This implementation is NOT ready for production use.

Name: arkworks/sponge
Description: This library is archived; see crypto-primities for the latest version of this code
Disclaimer: WARNING: This is an academic prototype, and in particular has not received careful code review. This implementation is NOT ready for production use.

Name: arkworks/std
Description: A standard library wrapper for use in the `arkworks` ecosystem
Disclaimer: WARNING: This is an academic proof-of-concept prototype, and in particular has not received careful code review. This implementation is NOT ready for production use.

Name: bulletproofs (sdiehl)
Description: Bulletproofs are short non-interactive zero-knowledge proofs that require no trusted setup
Disclaimer: This is experimental code meant for research-grade projects only. Please do not use this code in production until it has matured significantly.

Name: libsnark
Description: C++ library for zkSNARKs
Disclaimer: This code is a research-quality proof of concept, and has not yet undergone extensive review or testing. It is thus not suitable, as is, for use in critical or production systems.

Name: miden-vm
Description: STARK-based virtual machine
Disclaimer: WARNING: This project is in an alpha stage. It has not been audited and may contain bugs and security flaws. This implementation is NOT ready for production use.

Name: plonky
Description: Recursive SNARKs based on Plonk and Halo
Disclaimer: This code has not been thoroughly reviewed or tested, and should not be used in any production systems.

Name: plonky2
Type Notes: https://polymerlabs.medium.com/a-tutorial-on-writing-zk-proofs-with-plonky2-part-i-be5812f6b798 - requires you to write circuits. ‚ÄúWhile plonky2 or other zk proof libraries may provide other functions to model your computation on, those functions are ultimately just higher-level arithmetic circuits.‚Äù
Disclaimer: This code has not yet been audited, and should not be used in any production systems.

Name: pysnark
Description: Python-based system for zk-SNARK based verifiable computations and smart contracts
Type Notes: little documentation and resources. https://meilof.github.io/pysnark/ can use libsnark, snarkjs as backend
Disclaimer: PySNARK may be used for non-commercial, experimental and research purposes. PySNARK is experimental and not fit for production environment. In particular, PySNARK does not use cryptographically secure randomness!

Name: winterfell
Description: A STARK prover and verifier for arbitrary computations
Type Notes: Some abstraction, but still non trivial. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q8xYSOx82U0
Disclaimer: WARNING: This is a research project. It has not been audited and may contain bugs and security flaws. This implementation is NOT ready for production use.

Name: bellman
Description: zk-SNARK library.

Name: bulletproofs
Description: A pure-Rust implementation of Bulletproofs using Ristretto.

Name: snarkjs
Description: zkSNARK implementation in JavaScript & WASM

Name: cairo-lang
Type Notes: Starknet suite may contain learning curve but a lot of support. The disadvantage, in my opinion, is that Cairo is not easy. It is similar to assembly code and has a lot steeper learning curve. Another point worth mentioning is that it is a language being developed, so you will not be able to find all the errors, and lots is missing in terms of documentation and functionality at the moment. You will also need to maintain the repo to have the latest updates as you are writing code. There are not many educational guides as well.  Abstracts ZKP, but cairo-lang is assembly like

Name: circom
Description: zkSnark circuit compiler
Type Notes: It is designed as a low-level circuit language, mimicking the design of electronic circuits, for naturally defining Arithmetic circuits.

Name: circomlib
Description: Library of basic circuits for circom

Name: gnark
Description: gnark is a fast zk-SNARK library that offers a high-level API to design circuits. The library is open source and developed under the Apache 2.0 license
Type Notes: fast zk-SNARK library that offers a high-level API to design circuits
Disclaimer: gnark has been partially audited and is provided as-is, we make no guarantees or warranties to its safety and reliability. In particular, gnark makes no security guarantees such as constant time implementation or side-channel attack resistance.

Name: halo2
Type Notes: Halo2 is specific to PLONKish, giving you very direct control of how circuits are represented in the arithmetization. This makes Halo2 very low-level, but ideal for writing highly optimized circuits.

Name: leo
Description: ü¶Å The Leo Programming Language. A Programming Language for Formally Verified, Zero-Knowledge Applications
Type Notes: Don‚Äôt have to know the inner workings of ZKPs - it is done behind the scenes.

Name: merlin
Description: Composable proof transcripts for public-coin arguments of knowledge

Name: openzkp
Description: OpenZKP - pure Rust implementations of Zero-Knowledge Proof systems.
Type Notes: https://medium.com/@recmo/introducing-openzkp-1dea6b22dceb No high-level language.Constraints are specified using their algebraic expressions. This requires complicated and careful design from the library user and is easy to do wrong, leading to insecure systems. A high level language would help make development simpler and safer and facilitate re-use of components.
Disclaimer:
That being said, it also has a number of limitations, it has
no high-level language,
no comprehensive security audit,
no perfect zero-knowledge,
hard-coded field and hash function,
and some others, see features and limitations below for details.

Name: plonky3
Description: A collection of libraries related to polynomial IOPs (PIOPs)

Name: risc0
Description: RISC Zero is a zero-knowledge verifiable general computing platform based on zk-STARKs and the RISC-V microarchitecture.
Type Notes: Developers interact with RISC Zero by simply writing code and the service handles all the backend complexity.
Disclaimer: That said, this code is still under heavy development and has not been audited. There may be bugs in the zk-STARK implementation, the arithmetic circuit used to instantiate the RISC-V zkVM, or any other element of the code's implementation. Such bugs may impact the security of receipts, leak information, or cause any other manner of problems. Caveat emptor. WARNING: This software is still experimental, we do not recommend it for production use.

Name: zksync
Description: zkSync: trustless scaling and privacy engine for Ethereum
